message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question are classic features of Fragile X syndrome. This genetic disorder is caused by an expansion of CGG repeats on the FMR1 gene, and a PCR and DNA sequencing can confirm the diagnosis. Huntington's disease, Myotonic dystrophy type 1, and Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy present with different clinical features and are caused by different genetic mutations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of macroorchidism, hypertelorism, large protruding ears, a large jaw, and a long thin face suggest Fragile X syndrome. The expansion of 250 repeats of CGG confirms the diagnosis. None of the other options are associated with Fragile X syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described, along with the expansion of 250 repeats of CGG on PCR and DNA sequencing, indicate the diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome. Huntington's disease presents in adulthood, while myotonic dystrophy type 1 and spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy do not have the same characteristic macroorchidism and facial features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are consistent with Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by an expansion of CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene. The diagnosis is confirmed by PCR and DNA sequencing. Huntington's disease and Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy are caused by expansions of CAG repeats, while Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is caused by an expansion of CTG repeats.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The expansion of 250 CGG repeats is a characteristic feature of Fragile X syndrome, which is commonly associated with macroorchidism, hypertelorism, large protruding ears, a large jaw, and a long thin face. Huntington's disease is caused by a CAG repeat expansion, and Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is caused by a CTG repeat expansion. Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy is caused by a CAG repeat expansion in the androgen receptor gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are classic features of Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by an expansion of the CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene. The number of CGG repeats determines the severity of the syndrome, with more than 200 repeats resulting in a full mutation and severe intellectual disability. Huntington's disease is caused by a repeat expansion of CAG, and Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is caused by a repeat expansion of CTG. Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy is caused by a repeat expansion of CAG in the androgen receptor gene. However, none of the other diagnoses fit with the symptoms described in the case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fragile X syndrome is caused by an expansion of CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene. The symptoms of the boy, including macroorchidism, hypertelorism, large protruding ears, a large jaw, and a long thin face, are consistent with Fragile X syndrome. Huntington's disease is caused by a CAG expansion, while Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is caused by CTG expansion and Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy is caused by a CAG expansion in a different gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including macroorchidism, hypertelorism, and large protruding ears, suggest Fragile X Syndrome. The expansion of 250 CGG repeats is characteristic of this genetic disorder. None of the other options present with these symptoms or genetic mutation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of macroorchidism, hypertelorism, large protruding ears, a large jaw, and a long thin face are commonly seen in Fragile X syndrome. The expansion of 250 repeats of CGG in the FMR1 gene confirms the diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome, which is an X-linked dominant genetic disorder affecting the FMR1 gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms listed (macroorchidism, hypertelorism, large protruding ears, a large jaw, and a long thin face) are characteristic of Fragile X syndrome. The expansion of 250 repeats of CGG confirms the diagnosis as Fragile X syndrome, as individuals with this condition have a large number of repeats on the FMR1 gene. Huntington's disease is caused by a repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene, myotonic dystrophy type 1 is caused by a repeat expansion in the DMPK gene, and spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy is caused by a repeat expansion in the androgen receptor gene, none of which are associated with the symptoms described.
